paper_metadata.title: MAIN TEXT
paper_metadata.extraction_summary: Extracted information on the TTR gene variant V122I, including penetrance data and individual case details.

patients.phenotype: hereditary transthyretin amyloidosis (hATTR) with cardiac involvement

individual_records.phenotype_details: cardiac amyloidosis with heart failure symptoms
individual_records.evidence_sentence: In ∼3.4% of populations with ancestral origins from coastal west Africa and clinical signs of hATTR, a high frequency of the TTR V122I (pV142I) allele can be observed.
In ∼3.4% of populations with ancestral origins from coastal west Africa and clinical signs of hATTR, a high frequency of the TTR V122I (pV142I) allele can be observed.
In ∼3.4% of populations with ancestral origins from coastal west Africa and clinical signs of hATTR, a high frequency of the TTR V122I (pV142I) allele can be observed.

functional_data.summary: The TTR V122I variant is associated with increased amyloid fibril formation.

variants.segregation_data: Segregates with disease in families with hATTR.
variants.population_frequency: Observed in approximately 3.4% of populations with ancestral origins from coastal west Africa.
variants.additional_notes: The V122I variant is the most common mutation associated with hATTR.
key_quotes: The most common mutation associated with hATTR is the V122I (pV142I) allele.
hATTR diagnosis is often delayed, with a late diagnosis often translating into two to 3 years of remaining life expectancy.

extraction_metadata.notes: Data was extracted thoroughly from the main text.
